awd_titl_txt: Evaluating the Roles of the Ocean, the Atmosphere, and External Forcing in Atlantic Multi-Decadal Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
Sea surface temperatures (SSTs) over the Atlantic north of the equator show a form of variability in which the entire basin slowly warms and cools, which is referred to as Atlantic Multidecadal Variability (AMV).  AMV can be characterized by the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO), formed as the average detrended SST in the North Atlantic (equator to 55 North) after smoothing. The roughly 100-year record of the AMO shows two cycles of oscillation, with cooler temperatures in the early 1900s, warming from the 1920s to about 1960, cooling again from the 1960s to around the millenium, and warming after that.  These temperature variations matter for the surrounding land areas as warmer SSTs are associated with increased rainfall in the southeast US and North Africa, increased hurricane activity, and warmer winters in Europe and North Africa.  Generally opposite conditions prevail when the AMO is in its cool phase, for example the Sahel drought occurred during the most recent cold period.

The driving mechanisms of AMV are not well understood.  Variations in the strength of the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC) are the most commonly invoked explanation for the slow fluctuations of the AMO, and simulations in which AMOC strength is deliberately reduced show an AMO-like SST response.  But recent work by the PIs and collaborators suggests that AMO-like variability can be produced in models which do not represent the AMOC.  They looked at climate model simulations in which the ocean model was replaced by a non-circulating "slab" representing the upper ocean, and these simulations produced the AMO SST pattern and behavior similar to standard climate models.  Other work suggests that AMO variability can be generated by external forcing factors such as and anthropogenic aerosols and volcanic aerosols.

In this project the PIs perform a series of numerical model experiments designed to address the roles of external forcing and oceanic and atmospheric processes in driving AMO variability, with further effort devoted to understanding AMO/AMV impacts on surrounding landmasses.  The work addresses three general questions:

1) How much is the ocean contributing to multi-decadal variations in the Atlantic basin? What are the dominant ocean processes responsible for this?

2) How much is the atmosphere contributing, including externally forced changes in composition, as well as cloud-radiative feedbacks?

3) What are the causes of the impacts associated with the AMV around the Atlantic basin?

These questions are addressed using a combination of diagnostic heat budget analysis and numerical experiments with a hierarchy of model configurations designed to isolate or eliminate particular processes.  In addition to the standard climate model and "slab" ocean model configurations discussed above, the PIs use an ocean model configuration in which each ocean column simulates vertical mixing but ocean circulation is still not simulated (see AGS-1650209).  Another configuration allows ocean circulation (including the AMOC) but does not allow changes in the surface winds to affect the circulation, thereby ruling out explanations in which winds and ocean currents act together to generate the AMO.  Research on the role of external forcing uses an aerosol dataset from the Max Planck Institute in which analytically specified plumes represent aerosols from the major emission centers. 

The work has societal as well as scientific relevance given the connections between AMO variability and surface climate on surrounding landmasses, including hurricane activity that affects the US east coast.  The work also promotes the development and use of a hierarchy of models connected to the freely available Community Earth System Model, and these model configurations will be made available to the research community.  In addition, the work supports a graduate student and includes outreach to K-12 students and the general public.

por.por_cntn:
The impacts of Atlantic multi-decadal climate variability (AMV) are widespread, but its causes remain uncertain. There are several leading candidates. Perhaps the most common is multi-decadal variability in the ocean circulation, in particular the Atlantic Meridional Overturning circulation (AMOC), which converges heat in the North Atlantic ocean. Another perspective is that variability in heat fluxes driven by stochastic atmospheric processes can explain basin-wide warming and cooling events in the North Atlantic. A third candidate is multi-decadal variations in external climate forcings, such as anthropogenic aerosols, volcanic forcing, and solar variability. This project aims to quantifying the influence of these three processes, and understand what the implications are for prediction of the impacts on temperature and rainfall around the world. This project produced many papers, what have been published and presented widely by the entire team, in which we have shown that:

  • The decadal and multidecadal variations in the North Atlantic in recent decades are predominately forced by changes in external radiative forcing such as aerosols and greenhouse gases (Murphy et al. 2017, Bellomo et al. 2018, Waite et al. 2020, Klavans et al. 2022).
  • A simple noise forced analytic model low-passed, accounts for relations between heat fluxes and SST interpreted in much literature to imply a large role for ocean circulation in Atlantic climate modes (Cane et al, 2017).
  • Impacts that have been attributed to the AMV, such as Florida rainfall and hurricanes, the NAO, as well as connections between the North Atlantic and Pacific are also forced (Klavans et al. 2019, Kramer et al. 2019, Klavans et al. 2020, Fenske and Clement 2022). Note the press release for Klavans et al. 2020 (below).
  • Forced changes in atmospheric circulation can also produce a ‘warming hole’ in the trend of North Atlantic SST (He et al. 2022).
  • The variance in fully coupled CMIP models is lower than in observations (Murphy et al. 2017, Klavans et al. 2022)
  • This is not true of models with slab oceans, suggesting that the more complete ocean physics are damping excessively (Murphy et al. 2021)
  • Climate models have a lower signal to noise ratio than nature, resulting in the ‘signal to noise’ paradox (Zhang et al.  2020, Klavans et al. 2021).
  • Claims based on models extrapolated to a correspondingly large role for internal variability in North Atlantic climate in nature are inconsistent with the signal to noise paradox (Klavans et al. 2021, 2022)
  • Klavans et al (2021) shows that the signal in prediction comes almost entirely from external forcing rather than initial conditions. Note the press release on this paper below.

This project has provided partial support for several PhD and undergraduate students who have produced award-winning research, and numerous opportunities for professional development. This project has also helped to advance the career of an Instructor, who uses the research tools, methods, and findings in her classroom.

The impacts of long-term changes in rainfall, seasonal temperature extremes, and hurricane activity are challenging to manage, and there is demand for information about these (and other) climate quantities with lead times of decades, as well as an assessment of the uncertainty in this information.  Understanding how much variability in these quantities can be tied to radiative forcing is critical. For example, early motivation for understanding the AMO and AMV came from the observation that Florida rainfall is strongly positively correlated. If the AMO is in internal mode, one would expect that low rainfall amounts associated with low AMO may return in the future. However, if both the rainfall and AMO are driven by the forcing (as we have found in this project), it may not be reasonable to expect a repeat of those values in the future as anthropogenic forcing becomes an even stronger influence. The PI has actively participated in the planning and research in local climate adaptation in South Florida, through her role as vice chair of the City of Miami Climate Resilience Committee, and co-director of the Resilient305 Research Collaborative. This project has provided an improved scientific basis for future projections of regional changes in the SE US, as well as other regions, that PI Clement will use to inform discussions of science-based equitable regional climate adaptation.
